factoid: The night was dark but starry.
The road showed black in the snow that had fallen the previous day.
The previous day was the day of the battle.
Prince Andrew was reviewing his impressions of the recent battle.
Prince Andrew was picturing pleasantly to himself the impression his news of a victory would create.
Prince Andrew was recalling the send-off given to him by the commander in chief and his fellow officers.
Prince Andrew was galloping along in a post chaise.
Prince Andrew was enjoying the feelings of a man who had at length begun to attain a long‑desired happiness.
When Prince Andrew closed his eyes, his ears seemed filled with the rattle of the wheels.
When Prince Andrew closed his eyes, his ears seemed filled with the sensation of victory.
Prince Andrew began to imagine that the Russians were running away.
Prince Andrew imagined that he himself was killed.
Prince Andrew quickly roused himself with a feeling of joy.
Prince Andrew learned that the Russians were not running away but that the French had run away.
Prince Andrew recalled all the details of the victory.
Prince Andrew recalled his own calm courage during the battle.
Prince Andrew felt reassured.
Prince Andrew dozed off.
The dark starry night was followed by a bright cheerful morning.
The snow was thawing in the sunshine.
The horses galloped quickly.
On both sides of the road were forests of different kinds, fields, and villages.
At one of the post stations, Prince Andrew overtook a convoy of Russian wounded.
The Russian officer in charge of the transport lolled back in the front cart.
The Russian officer shouted and scolded a soldier with coarse abuse.
In each of the long German carts, six or more pale, dirty, bandaged men were being jolted over the stony road.
Some of those men were talking.
Those men were speaking Russian words.
Some of those men were eating bread.
The more severely wounded looked silently at the envoy hurrying past them.
The more severely wounded had the languid interest of sick children.
Prince Andrew told his driver to stop.
Prince Andrew asked a soldier what action the convoy had been wounded.
The soldier answered that the convoy had been wounded on the Danube the day before yesterday.
Prince Andrew took out his purse and gave the soldier three gold pieces.
Prince Andrew said to the officer that that was for them all.
Prince Andrew told the officer to get well soon, lads.
Prince Andrew told the officer that there was plenty to do still.
The officer asked Prince Andrew what news.
Prince Andrew shouted good news to the driver.
Prince Andrew shouted go on to the driver.
Prince Andrew and the driver galloped on.
It was already quite dark when Prince Andrew rattled over the paved streets of Brünn.
Prince Andrew found himself surrounded by high buildings.
The lights of shops, houses, and street lamps were present.
Fine carriages were present.
The atmosphere of a large and active town was present.
The town was always so attractive to a soldier after camp life.
Despite his rapid journey and sleepless night, Prince Andrew felt even more vigorous and alert than he had felt the day before.
Prince Andrew's eyes gleamed feverishly.
Prince Andrew's thoughts followed one another with extraordinary clearness and rapidity.
Prince Andrew vividly recalled the details of the battle.
The recalled details were no longer dim but definite and in the concise form in which he imagined himself stating them to Emperor Francis.
Prince Andrew vividly imagined casual questions that might be put to him.
Prince Andrew vividly imagined the answers he would give.
Prince Andrew expected to be at once presented to Emperor Francis.
At the chief entrance to the palace, an official came running out to meet Prince Andrew.
The official learned that Prince Andrew was a special messenger.
The official led Prince Andrew to another entrance.
The official told Prince Andrew to go to the right from the corridor and that there he would find the adjutant on duty.
The official told Prince Andrew that the adjutant would conduct him to the Minister of War.
The adjutant on duty met Prince Andrew and asked him to wait.
The adjutant went in to the Minister of War.
Five minutes later the adjutant returned.
The adjutant bowed with particular courtesy.
The adjutant ushered Prince Andrew before him along a corridor to the cabinet where the Minister of War was at work.
The adjutant by his elaborate courtesy appeared to wish to ward off any attempt at familiarity on the part of the Russian messenger.
